<SectionDefinition>

## Protected Member Attributes

### KnownUBInsts {#ad88e8706977b3f4bec9f1dffb90f4dd7}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>SmallPtrSet&lt;Instruction &#42;, 8&gt; anonymous&#95;namespace&#123;AttributorAttributes.cpp&#125;::AAUndefinedBehaviorImpl::KnownUBInsts</>}
  labels = {["protected"]}>
Note: The correctness of this analysis depends on the fact that the following 2 sets will stop changing after some point.

&quot;Change&quot; here means that their size changes. The size of each set is monotonically increasing (we only add items to them) and it is upper bounded by the number of instructions in the processed function (we can never save more elements in either set than this number). Hence, at some point, they will stop increasing. Consequently, at some point, both sets will have stopped changing, effectively making the analysis reach a fixpoint. Note: These 2 sets are disjoint and an instruction can be considered one of 3 things: 1) Known to cause UB (AAUndefinedBehavior could prove it) and put it in the KnownUBInsts set. 2) Assumed to cause UB (in every updateImpl, AAUndefinedBehavior has a reason to assume it). 3) Assumed to not cause UB. very other instruction - AAUndefinedBehavior could not find a reason to assume or prove that it can cause UB, hence it assumes it doesn&#39;t. We have a set for these instructions so that we don&#39;t reprocess them in every update. Note however that instructions in this set may cause UB. A set of all live instructions <em>known</em> to cause UB.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/ipo/attributorattributes-cpp/#l03227">3227</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/ipo/attributorattributes-cpp">AttributorAttributes.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>
